Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Architecture Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems (ASPLOS) 2018 Student Travel Grant Proposal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports travel to the 23rd ACM International Conference on Architectural Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems, to be held in Williamsburg, VA,on March 24-28, 2018. ASPLOS is a premier forum for multidisciplinary systems research spanning computer architecture and hardware, programming languages and compilers, and operating systems. Papers in ASPLOS may target diverse goals such as performance, energy and thermal efficiency, resiliency, security, and sustainability.


This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Conference on Architecture Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems (ASPLOS) is a premier forum for multidisciplinary systems research spanning computer architecture and hardware, programming languages and compilers, operating systems and networking, as well as applications and user interfaces. The funding supported this highly regarded conference by obtaining travel support for students in order to defray the costs of attending and participating in the ASPLOS conference in March 2018 in Williamsburg, VA, USA. In addition, the conference held a shadow program committee to allow systems researchers (PhD students, post- docs and new faculty members) to get experience in community service.

21 out of the 38 students who received travel support were female or under-represented.  

The funding enabled three primary direct benefits. First, the ASPLOS conference was strengthened as a result of the greater attendance that this travel support enabled. Second, those students receiving travel support personally benefited from the opportunity to interact with peers and experts, as well as establish connections that helps their professional careers. Third, the attendants to the shadow PC meeting gained the valuable experience in community service. More broadly, we experienced additional indirect impacts. First, we widely advertised the available support in order to attract women and under-represented minority groups (through postings on programming languages, systems, computer architecture web-sites and mailing lists). Second, by focusing on students, the grant helped foster the mentoring of subsequent generations of computer systems researchers.
